title: Despite the hype, the majority of the Big Ten is mediocre
text:
The Big Ten has money, fans and coverage, but in the past decade they haven’t had depth. Save for Ohio State, Michigan and occasionally Penn State; no other Big Ten team consistently does anything special throughout the fall. The middle and lower tiers of the conference have struggled to stay competitive, often cycling through coaches, rebuilding phases and less than impressive seasons. As a result, the conference’s reputation has leaned heavily on a small handful of elite programs who disguise the true mediocrity of the Big Ten.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(gt)
library(ggrepel)


record25 <- read_csv("Record25.csv") |> mutate(Season = 2025)
record24 <- read_csv("Record24.csv") |> mutate(Season = 2024)
record23 <- read_csv("Record23.csv") |> mutate(Season = 2023)
record22 <- read_csv("Record22.csv") |> mutate(Season = 2022)
record21 <- read_csv("Record21.csv") |> mutate(Season = 2021)
record20 <- read_csv("Record20.csv") |> mutate(Season = 2020)
record19 <- read_csv("Record19.csv") |> mutate(Season = 2019)
record18 <- read_csv("Record18.csv") |> mutate(Season = 2018)
record17 <- read_csv("Record17.csv") |> mutate(Season = 2017)
record16 <- read_csv("Record16.csv") |> mutate(Season = 2016)
record15 <- read_csv("Record15.csv") |> mutate(Season = 2015)
record14 <- read_csv("Record14.csv") |> mutate(Season = 2014)



records <- bind_rows(record25, record24, record23, record22, record21, record20, record19, record18, record17, record16, record15, record14) |> 
  mutate(
    Conf = gsub(" (West)", "", Conf, fixed=TRUE),
    Conf = gsub(" (East)", "", Conf, fixed=TRUE),
    TeamSeason = paste(School, Season)
    )



p4 <- c("ACC", "SEC", "Big Ten", "Big 12")

big10 <- c("Rutgers", "Purdue", "Northwestern", "Nebraska", "Minnesota", "Michigan State","Maryland", "Indiana", "Illinois")



losers <- records |> 
  filter(Conf %in% p4) |> 
  filter(Season != 2025) |> 
  filter(Pct < .5) |> 
  group_by (School, Conf, SRS, SOS) |> 
  tally(sort=TRUE) |> 
  ungroup() |> 
  top_n(15, wt=n)

big10loser <- records |> 
  filter(Conf == "Big Ten") |> 
  filter(Season != 2025) |> 
  filter(Pct < .5) |> 
  group_by (School, Conf, SRS, SOS) |> 
  tally(sort=TRUE) |> 
  ungroup()


bad <- records |> filter(SOS < -15)
loserseasons <- records |> filter(School %in% losers$School) |> filter(Pct < .5)
good <- records |> filter(SRS > 30)



ggplot() +
  geom_point(data = records, aes(x = SOS, y = SRS), color="grey") + 
  geom_point(data=loserseasons, aes(x = SOS, y = SRS), color="orange") +
  geom_point(data=big10loser, aes(x = SOS, y = SRS), color="blue") +
  geom_smooth(data = records, aes(x = SOS, y = SRS), method="lm", se=FALSE) +
  geom_point(data=bad, aes(x = SOS, y = SRS), color="red") +  
  geom_text_repel(data=bad, aes(x=SOS, y=SRS, label=TeamSeason)) +
   geom_point(data=good, aes(x = SOS, y = SRS), color="green") + 
     geom_text_repel(data=good, aes(x=SOS, y=SRS, label=TeamSeason)) +
labs(
    x="Strength of Schedule", 
    y="Simple Rating System", 
    title="Big Ten football remains average", 
    subtitle="The grey dots show every FBS season since 2014. Of the 260 Power Four teams with losing-season streaks \n(orange) each conference would account for 65. Big Ten teams with losing-season streaks (blue) come in at 68, \nhighlighting a decade of pretty average, middle of the pack football.",
    caption="Source: Sports Reference | By Emma Baumgart"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 









Looking at every team over the past decade can make it hard to notice just how unremarkable most of the Big Ten has been, but narrowing the focus to the 24 programs with the longest losing records over that span makes the picture clearer. The Big Ten accounts for nine of those 24 teams and holds five of the longest losing-season streaks trailing only Vanderbilt and Kansas. Those aren’t programs Big Ten teams should be happy about being grouped with, especially for a conference that prides itself on a long history of success.
Before the conference realignment, this would mean over half of the Big Ten had a losing record within the decade. Now, even with the conference expanding, it means that half of its teams appear on the list.


Code
p4 <- c("ACC", "SEC", "Big Ten", "Big 12")

loserstable <- records |> 
  filter(Conf %in% p4) |> 
  filter(Season != 2025) |> 
  filter(Pct < .5) |> 
  group_by (School, Conf) |> 
  summarise(
    n = n(),
    avg_wins = round(mean(W), 1)
  ) |> 
  ungroup() |> 
  top_n(15, wt=n)


loserstable |> 
  gt() |> 
  cols_label(
    Conf = "Conference",
    n = "Losing Seasons",
    avg_wins= "Average Wins"
  ) |> 
  tab_header(
    title = "Losing tradition? Big Ten overrepresented among struggling programs",
    subtitle = "The Big Ten contributes nine teams to the top 24 teams with a losing record, that means half of the Big Ten has long standing losing streaks."
  ) |> 
  tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")
  ) |> 
  tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")
  ) |>
  tab_source_note(
    source_note = md("**By:** Emma Baumgart | **Source:** Sports Reference")) |>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "orange"),
      cell_text(color = "white")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = Conf == "Big Ten")
  )

By: Emma Baumgart | Source: Sports Reference








However, hope is not lost for the Big Ten. Most of the teams who have spent years stuck in losing seasons are slowly showing signs of life. Several of the teams that once helped drag down the conference’s reputation are beginning to claw their way back toward the Big Ten’s winning ideals. In fact, throughout the 2025 season, Illinois and Michigan State stick out as the only two of the nine Big Ten teams on these lists who are not showing signs of upward momentum.
Comparatively, looking at the teams from the Big 12 and SEC, only Kansas, Kentucky, Mississippi State, Texas Tech and Vanderbilt can claim they’re moving forward. The rest of the 15 remain on a downward slope or are evening out. So while the Big Ten’s lower tier may not be thriving quite yet, it does seem to be making steadier progress than its Power Four peers.


Code
loserrecordsovertime <- records |> 
  filter(School %in% loserstable$School)


ggplot() + 
  geom_hline(yintercept= 0.4910139, color="darkorange") + 
  geom_line(data=loserrecordsovertime, aes(x=Season, y=Pct, group=School)) + 
  facet_wrap(~School) +
labs(
    x="Season", 
    y="Percent", 
    title="Big Ten teams show signs of a 2025 rebound", 
    subtitle="Seven of the nine Big Ten teams are trending upward during the 2025 season, while only five of the 15 Power \nFour programs show similar progress.", 
    caption="Source: Sports Reference | By Emma Baumgart"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    )
